1.text: These are additional proverbs of Solomon, which were copied by the men of Hezekiah king of Judah:

2.text: It is the glory of God to conceal a matter and the glory of kings to search it out.

3.text: As the heavens are high and the earth is deep, so the hearts of kings cannot be searched.

4.text: Remove the dross from the silver, and a vessel for a silversmith will come forth.

5.text: Remove the wicked from the king’s presence, and his throne will be established in righteousness.

6.text: Do not exalt yourself in the presence of the king, and do not stand in the place of great men;

7.text: for it is better to be told, “Come up here!” than to be demoted in the presence of the prince. Even what you have seen with your own eyes,

8.text: do not bring hastily to court. Otherwise, what will you do in the end when your neighbor puts you to shame?

9.text: Argue your case with your neighbor without betraying another’s confidence,

10.text: lest he who hears you bring shame upon you, and your infamy never go away.

11.text: A word fitly spoken is like apples of gold in settings of silver.

12.text: Like an earring of gold or an ornament of fine gold is a wise man’s rebuke to a listening ear.

13.text: Like the cold of snow in the time of harvest is a trustworthy messenger to those who send him; he refreshes the soul of his masters.

14.text: Like clouds and wind without rain is the man who boasts of gifts never given.

15.text: Through patience a ruler can be persuaded, and a gentle tongue can break a bone.

16.text: If you find honey, eat just what you need, lest you have too much and vomit it up.

17.text: Seldom set foot in your neighbor’s house, lest he grow weary and hate you.

18.text: Like a club or sword or sharp arrow is a man who bears false witness against his neighbor.

19.text: Like a broken tooth or a foot out of joint is confidence in a faithless man in time of trouble.

20.text: Like one who removes a garment on a cold day or vinegar poured on a wound is one who sings songs to a heavy heart.

21.text: If your enemy is hungry, give him food to eat, and if he is thirsty, give him water to drink.

22.text: For in so doing, you will heap burning coals on his head, and the LORD will reward you.

23.text: As the north wind brings forth rain, so a backbiting tongue brings angry looks.

24.text: Better to live on a corner of the roof than to share a house with a quarrelsome wife.

25.text: Like cold water to a weary soul is good news from a distant land.

26.text: Like a muddied spring or a polluted well is a righteous man who gives way to the wicked.

27.text: It is not good to eat too much honey or to search out one’s own glory.

28.text: Like a city whose walls are broken down is a man who does not control his temper.
